Core Course: Building Knowledge and Expertise in Infrastructure Finance
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Fumika Ouchi Advisor Evaluation Analyst (202) 458-5625 (202) 473-5058
Number 30 March 1999
Dailami, Mansoor The Regulatory Reform and Private Enterprise Division of WBI (WBIRP) conducted a core course on Building Knowledge and Expertise in Infrastructure Finance in Beirut, Lebanon from December 7-18, 1998. This was the third offering of the Infrastructure Finance series in 1998, following courses held in Seoul, Korea, in May and in Washington, D.C., in June. The objective of the course was to improve participants' understanding of the following areas of infrastructure finance: 1) analysis, management, and financing of infrastructure projects; 2) international best practices and state-of-the-art techniques in the process of concession rights award, contract design, and negotiation; 3) constraints and challenges faced by contracting parties; and 4) links between sectoral policy reforms, technologies, regulatory structures, and private finances. The course was attended by a total of 40 participants from 11 countries in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region, represented by government officials, private executives, and financiers in developing countries who were involved in infrastructure development and finance, as well as representatives from the Islamic Development Bank and the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development.
The WBI Evaluation Unit conducted a Level 1 (participants' reaction) evaluation using a participants' feedback questionnaire. The questionnaire consisted of three sections. The first section asked the extent to which the respondents were satisfied with course content and delivery. The second section asked the level of respondents knowledge about course topics before and after the course, based on self-assessment. A 5-point Likert type scale that ranged from 1=minimum to 5=maximum was used for the first time in this course offering for each question. The third section was respondents' open-ended comments about the course. The questionnaire was completed by 34 respondents, 85% of the total participants.
In the data analysis, this course was compared with the two previous 1998 course offerings that had the same course objectives. Since the courses in Korea and Washington, D. C. used a 6-point scale in their course evaluation, results of the Lebanon course were adjusted by using the scale adjustment factor described in an WBI's recent technical review (Gaur and Eckert, "Evaluating EDI Participant Reactions via Different Response Scales: A Technical Review," p.12-13,1998). The scale adjustment factor, 0.78, was added to the mean scores measured on a 5-point scale for course content and delivery in the Lebanon course, in order to compare scores obtained on a 6-point scale in Korea and Washington. The use of the adjustment factor provided comparability between mean scores measured on different scales across the three course offerings. Following is a summary of the evaluation findings.
Respondents' Background
l Table 1 summarizes key characteristics of respondents in the three course offerings. The Lebanon course was represented by a larger percentage of respondents from the public sector (91.2%), compared to the two previous courses in Korea (24.2%) and Washington, D.C (65.5%). The Lebanon course also had a higher proportion of respondents with advanced academic degrees. Twenty-eight out of the 34 respondents in Lebanon (82.4%) reported to have had either masters degrees or equivalent (N=23) or doctorate degrees (N=5), whereas 28.8% in Korea and 74.5% in Washington had  the advanced degrees.
l The Lebanon course was different from the other two courses in another key demographic composition of respondents. Respondents in Lebanon were represented by those with more work experience in the area of infrastructure finance and development. Half of the respondents (50%) in the Lebanon course reported to have had at least 6 years of experience, while 18.2% in Korea and 40% in Washington had the similar length of experience in the area.
l The number of women respondents remained low for the Lebanon course. In the two previous course offerings, 1 out of 66 respondents (1.5%) in Korea and 10 out of 55 (18.2%) in Washington were women. The Lebanon course had 3 women respondents out of the total 34 respondents (8.8%).

Course Performance
l Table 2 shows respondents' ratings of how each course performed on five selected indicators measuring course content and delivery. Mean scores that were adjusted from a 5-point to 6-point scale ("adjusted means") were shown for the Lebanon course, along with the original scores measured on a 5-point scale.
l The overall usefulness of the course in Lebanon received a mean score of 3.82 on a 5- point scale, or an adjusted mean score of 4.60. This was the highest score among all course performance indicators for the Lebanon course. The usefulness of the lecture presentations (adjusted mean=4.49) and reading materials (adjusted mean=4.57) were also among the highest ratings. The adjusted mean scores fell between the two mean scores of Korea and Washington, indicating that the Lebanon course had a similar performance result with the two previous courses on these three indicators.
l Compared with the previous courses, the Lebanon course had relatively lower ratings on indicators measuring course content. The extent to which the course provided a variety of viewpoints (adjusted mean=4.22) and the course focused on issues of respondents' needs (adjusted mean=4.08) were reported much lower than the corresponding ratings for Korea (mean=4.50 for viewpoints and 4.42 for focus) and Washington (mean=4.36 and 4.44, respectively). The two ratings of course content were also among the lowest scores in all performance indicators measured in the  Lebanon course.
l In their written comments, respondents in the Lebanon course made a number of suggestions on how the course could improve its content and focus. They were: 1) break down the course into major infrastructure subject sector, such as telecommunication, power, and transportation, to concentrate more on each sector (N=7); 2) use more case studies and examples of specific regions (N=8); 3) organize small group sessions for more in-depth discussions of subjects (N=4); and 4) choose instructors from academic or private sector institutions who are specialized in the field (N=3).

l Pre/post knowledge assessment in Lebanon indicated that the respondents' understanding of all 9 key issues presented in the course improved after the course from the 2.24-3.12 range before the course to the 3.33-3.91 range after the course on a 5-point scale. Table 3 summarizes the percentage change between pre- and post- course mean scores of 4 selected topics by course offering. The largest gain in the reported pre/post change in Lebanon was on the "clear systems of risk identification and allocation," which had one of the lowest pre-course mean scores but the rating increased by 64% after the course. This topic was also reported as having the largest positive pre/post gain among respondents in Korea (52.6%) and Washington (57.9%).
l The "limited resource project financing as applied to infrastructure transactions" was another topic that had a substantial pre/post gain among all respondents in the Lebanon course (56.8%). The gain was also larger than that observed in Washington (41.6%) and particularly, compared with the gain in Korea (33%). In the Lebanon course, this topic was reported to have had the largest effect on the respondents who had less than 6 years of work experience in infrastructure finance (N=17). Twelve out of the 17 respondents with less than 6 years of experience (71%) reported either 1 or 2 on a 5-point scale on this topic, creating the lowest mean score before the course for this group of respondents. Their post-course ratings improved by 61%. This was the largest pre/post gain for the respondents who had relatively fewer years of work experience in the Lebanon course.
l Across the three course offerings, respondents reported the smallest pre/post change  Across the three course offerings, respondents reported the smallest pre/post change on the "role of contracting." While the post-course mean score on this topic was among the highest in each course offering, respondents also indicated a high degree of familiarity with the topic before entering the course. This resulted in a small pre/post difference for each course. Another topic on contract, "how to develop a contract," was among the most familiar topics for the respondents in Lebanon before the course. Their pre-course knowledge level of this topic was one of the highest, and the pre/post change was one of the smallest (28.9%).
l Course organizer should be reminded that the two topics on contract (the "role of contracting" and "how to develop a contract") were also found to be the items that showed the largest knowledge gap between respondents of different work background at the end of the Lebanon course. Results by years of work experience indicated that post-course knowledge levels reported by the respondents with 6 years or more experience were higher than the levels reported by those with less than 6 years of experience across topics (difference in mean scores ranging from +0.19 to +0.46 point on a 5-point scale). Their difference was much larger on two contract issues (difference ranging from 0.8 to 0.9), showing the largest difference in the level of knowledge between the two groups of respondents.
l Learning gain was based on the respondents' self-assessment in each course offering. The pre/post changes observed in the three courses, therefore, did not reflect how much the respondents actually learned in each course. The course organizer is encouraged to use a measure that could capture the level of respondents' learning, such as the administration of a set of questions on course topics before and after the course.
